key_insight: TICON uses slide-level transformer attention to contextualize individual tile embeddings, producing rich, location-aware tile representations that capture both local morphology and global slide context in a single, reusable embedding.
problem_solved: Standard pipelines encode tiles independently, losing critical slide-level context required for accurate local (e.g., patch classification) and global (e.g., slide-level prognosis) tasks in histopathology. TICON fills this gap by re-infusing contextual information into tile features.
method: Start with off-the-shelf tile encoders to extract per-tile features, then aggregate tiles from the same whole-slide image into a sequence.
Apply a lightweight transformer-based contextualizer over the tile sequence to exchange information across spatially distributed tiles and produce contextualized tile embeddings.
Output slide-aware tile representations that can be plugged into any downstream task (local patch models, slide-level classifiers, multiple-instance learning) without retraining the base encoder.
impact: Provides practitioners a modular way to upgrade existing tile-based workflows with slide-aware features, improving interpretability and performance for both local and global pathology tasks while keeping compatibility with existing encoders and pipelines.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: raw WSI -> tile encoder -> tile sequence -> TICON transformer -> contextualized tile embeddings -> downstream tasks
Attention/heatmap overlay: example WSI showing how contextualized tile embeddings change attention or predicted importance across the slide
Before vs After comparison: t-SNE or UMAP of tile embeddings without context vs with TICON to show improved clustering/separation
Icon set: transformer block, tile grid/slide, plugin/module symbol indicating compatibility with existing encoders
paper_title: TICON: A Slide-Level Tile Contextualizer for Histopathology Representation Learning
paper_authors: Varun Belagali, Saarthak Kapse, Pierre Marza, Srijan Das, Zilinghan Li
